Hi Jeff, I got a real kick out of this story.  It's true it's practically=
 verbatim the kind of thing I've been talking about.  I love the sanctimoni=
ous voice of authority proclaiming, "A scientifically rigorous analysis mus=
t be given!"  It sounds almost like a directive passed down from from the e=
mperor of GECCO.  And so ironic given that the reviewer nevertheless openly=
 admits finding the results "very impressive." The cognitive dissonance mus=
t be painful.  Thanks for the perfect example of the p-value police run amo=
k.

Best,

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:=

>
> > Hi Jeff, congrats on this excellent work. That's great that IEEE pic=
ked it up so fast, but I'm not surprised they like it. All the attention sh=
ows there's something intuitively appealing that feels natural about this d=
omain. Maybe it could also succeed on Slashdot.
> > 
> > 
> Thanks Ken. Sin=
ce the IEEE post, the video has gone viral (ish). NBC did a story on it (ht=
tp://goo.gl/OJldm) and it was on the front page of BuzzFeed, reddit/r/scien=
ce, and even Youtube's "most popular videos" page. So far it's received 68,=
500 views in around 48 hours. It's been fun to watch people get so excited =
about this sort of work. 
> 
> It would be great if it got Slashdotted. I h=
ave been hoping it might happen on its own, but if it doesn't we may try to=
 submit something early next week. 
> 
> > I also wanted to make a slightly=
 more controversial point of praise, which I hope you don't mind, but one o=
f my favorite parts of the paper is this:
> > 
> > "Because it is notorious=
ly difficult to quantify attributes
> > such as "impressiveness" and "compl=
exity", we make no effort
> > to do so here. Instead, we attempt to visuall=
y represent
> > the interesting diversity of morphologies and behaviors tha=
t
> > evolved once evolution was provided with more materials
> > and a sop=
histicated encoding."
> > 
> > I really appreciated the open acknowledgment=
 of the potential pretense of these kinds of measures. Given the recognitio=
n this paper is already receiving, it's nice to see that sometimes people c=
an agree that something is interesting simply by looking at it rather than =
through a mysterious quantification that no one really understands. (Althou=
gh of course that doesn't mean measuring something is always bad either, bu=
t it does tend to be overemphasized in many cases.)
> > 
> Thanks. I agree.=
 But, as you've said many times, reviewers don't like evaluating subjective=
 things on their own, and they lean on p-values and demand meaningless quan=
titative comparisons because they are uncomfortable not having an excuse to=
 accept/reject a paper. I love quantitative measures and p-values when they=
 help, but I think it is unfortunate that many reviewers think that they ar=
e *necessary* for publication. 
> 
> I actually submitted another paper to =
GECCO that was rejected that was similar to this work in that it showed int=
eresting visual results, but did not attempt to force a quantification or e=
xperimental comparison that would have been uninformative. The response? A =
rejection, with comments like this one:
> 
> "The paper is grammatically we=
ll written, and organized. There are many illustrations showing the a varie=
ty of evolved results. They all look very impressive, and the system certai=
nly seems to have promise.
> 
> Unfortunately, there is absolutely no empir=
ical analysis included in the paper to support this research. Therefore, th=
is paper is not suitable for academic publication in its current form. A sc=
ientifically rigorous analysis must be given, which is expected for all sci=
entific papers in evolutionary computation, and GECCO in particular. Issues=
 that must be addressed include: evolutionary performance; statistical like=
lihood of solution quality; effects of experimental parameters; effects of =
target models; etc."
> 
> When I read that I thought: "This is exactly what=
 Ken has been complaining about!" It's everything you've been saying about =
reviewers distilled into one comment. They like the ideas and results, and =
thought the technical advance was impressive and new, but because I didn't =
present numbers and p-values they rejected it. Apparently if I had fiddled =
with the parameters a bit and showed them plots and p-vlaues=85which would =
not have shed any light on the main innovation of the paper=85then they wou=
ld have had an excuse to accept the paper. I was shocked to see this view e=
xpressed so explicitly!
> 
> 
> -Jeff

> > > Abstract: In 1994 Karl Sims showed that computational evo=
lution can produce interesting morphologies that resemble natural organisms=
. Despite nearly two decades of work since, evolved morphologies are not ob=
viously more complex or natural, and the field seems to have hit a complexi=
ty ceiling. One hypothesis for the lack of increased complexity is that mos=
t work, including Sims', evolves morphologies composed of rigid elements, s=
uch as solid cubes and cylinders, limiting the design space. A second hypot=
hesis is that the encodings of previous work have been overly regular, not =
allowing complex regularities with variation. Here we test both hypotheses =
by evolving soft robots with multiple materials and a powerful generative e=
ncoding called a compositional pattern-producing network (CPPN). Robots are=
 selected for locomotion speed. We find that CPPNs evolve faster robots tha=
n a direct encoding and that the CPPN morphologies appear more natural. We =
also find that locomotion performance increases as more materials are added=
, that diversity of form and behavior can be increased with different cost =
functions without stifling performance, and that organisms can be evolved a=
t different levels of resolution. These findings suggest the ability of gen=
erative soft-voxel systems to scale towards evolving a large diversity of c=
omplex, natural, multi-material creatures. Our results suggest that future =
work that combines the evolution of CPPN-encoded soft, multi-material robot=
s with modern diversity-encouraging techniques could finally enable the cre=
ation of creatures far more complex and interesting than those produced by =
Sims nearly twenty years ago.
